body_html:
Yes but when you start with a dense tensor, the zero value can mean anything when it comes to CTC labels. 0 does not always mean end of sentence or padding. For example, -1 is also a perfectly reasonable padding label value.
…

A matrix or tensor is said to be sparse if most of its elements are zero, and so this representation is much more economical (although operating with it is generally more complex). — You are receiving this because you were mentioned. body_text:
Yes but when you start with a dense tensor, the zero value can mean
anything when it comes to CTC labels.  0 does not always mean end of
sentence or padding. For example, -1 is also a perfectly reasonable padding
label value.
…
On Sun, Jan 14, 2018, 6:10 PM Jerome ***@***.***> wrote:
 Apparently, that number is not arbitrary according to this comment in this
 SO post
 <https://stackoverflow.com/questions/39838234/sparse-matrix-from-a-dense-one-tensorflow/41676814?noredirect=1#comment83489373_41676814>
 :

 A sparse tensor is defined through its nonzero values (in TensorFlow, but
 also in about any algebra package that defines sparse structures). A matrix
 or tensor is said to be sparse if most of its elements are zero, and so
 this representation is much more economical (although operating with it is
 generally more complex).

body:
Yes but when you start with a dense tensor, the zero value can mean
anything when it comes to CTC labels.  0 does not always mean end of
sentence or padding. For example, -1 is also a perfectly reasonable padding
label value.

On Sun, Jan 14, 2018, 6:10 PM Jerome <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Apparently, that number is not arbitrary according to this comment in this
> SO post
> <https://stackoverflow.com/questions/39838234/sparse-matrix-from-a-dense-one-tensorflow/41676814?noredirect=1#comment83489373_41676814>
> :
>
> A sparse tensor is defined through its nonzero values (in TensorFlow, but
> also in about any algebra package that defines sparse structures). A matrix
> or tensor is said to be sparse if most of its elements are zero, and so
> this representation is much more economical (although operating with it is
> generally more complex).
>
